Line 30: Line 30:
===Emergency law===
===Emergency law===
â
[[Emergency law in Egypt|Emergency Law]] (Law No. 162 of 1958) was enacted after the 1967 [[Six-Day War]], suspended for 18 months in the early 1980s,<ref name="emerlaw">[http://www.emerglobal.com/lex/law-1958-162 Law 1958/162 (Emergency Law)] {{ar}} at [http://www.emerglobal.com/lex EMERglobal Lex] January 2011, part of the [[Edinburgh Middle East Report]]. Retrieved 2 April 2010.</ref> and continuously in effect since [[Anwar El Sadat]]'s 1981 assassination.<ref name="eohr2008">{{cite web|last=Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights|title=Egypt and The Impact of 27 years of Emergency on Human Rights|url=http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110129202417/http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archivedate=29 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=28 May 2008}}</ref> Under the law, police powers are extended, [[Constitution of Egypt|constitutional rights]] suspended, [[censorship]] is legalised,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://conconflicts.ssrc.org/mideast/shehata/ |title=Egypt After 9/11: Perceptions of the United States |date=26 March 2004 |accessdate=30 January 2011 |last=Shehata |first=Samer |work=Contemporary Conflicts}}</ref> and the government may imprison individuals indefinitely and without reason. The law sharply limits any non-governmental political activity, including [[Demonstration (people)|street demonstrations]], non-approved political organisations, and unregistered financial donations.<ref name="emerlaw"/>
 
[[File:Day of Anger shoe sign.jpg|thumb|Demonstrator holding a sign (based on an [[open source]] [[:File:Hosni Mubarak getting the boot.png|Latuff editorial cartoon]]) depicting [[Shoeing|a shoe]] with "25 January" written inside it flying at Mubarak's face. In Arab culture, the soles of the shoes are considered unclean, thus displaying or striking with the sole of one's shoe is considered a grave insult.]]
[[File:Day of Anger shoe sign.jpg|thumb|Demonstrator holding a sign (based on an [[open source]] [[:File:Hosni Mubarak getting the boot.png|Latuff editorial cartoon]]) depicting [[Shoeing|a shoe]] with "25 January" written inside it flying at Mubarak's face. In Arab culture, the soles of the shoes are considered unclean, thus displaying or striking with the sole of one's shoe is considered a grave insult.]]
  +
[[Emergency law in Egypt|Emergency Law]] (Law No. 162 of 1958) was enacted after the 1967 [[Six-Day War]], suspended for 18 months in the early 1980s,<ref name="emerlaw">[http://www.emerglobal.com/lex/law-1958-162 Law 1958/162 (Emergency Law)] {{ar}} at [http://www.emerglobal.com/lex EMERglobal Lex] January 2011, part of the [[Edinburgh Middle East Report]]. Retrieved 2 April 2010.</ref> and continuously in effect since [[Anwar El Sadat]]'s 1981 assassination.<ref name="eohr2008">{{cite web|last=Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights|title=Egypt and The Impact of 27 years of Emergency on Human Rights|url=http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archiveurl=http://web.archive.org/web/20110129202417/http://en.eohr.org/2008/05/28/%E2%80%9Cegypt-and-the-impact-of-27-years-of-emergency-on-human-rights%E2%80%9D/#more-22|archivedate=29 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=28 May 2008}}</ref> Under the law, police powers are extended, [[Constitution of Egypt|constitutional rights]] suspended, [[censorship]] is legalised,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://conconflicts.ssrc.org/mideast/shehata/ |title=Egypt After 9/11: Perceptions of the United States |date=26 March 2004 |accessdate=30 January 2011 |last=Shehata |first=Samer |work=Contemporary Conflicts}}</ref> and the government may imprison individuals indefinitely and without reason. The law sharply limits any non-governmental political activity, including [[Demonstration (people)|street demonstrations]], non-approved political organisations, and unregistered financial donations.<ref name="emerlaw"/>
The Mubarak government has used the reason of [[terrorism]] to continue extending emergency law,<ref name="eohr2008"/> and has claimed that opposition groups like the [[Muslim Brotherhood#In Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] could come into power in Egypt if the current government did not forgo parliamentary elections, confiscate the group's main financiers' possessions, and detain group figureheadsâactions allowed under emergency law.<ref name="autogenerated2004">{{cite book |last= Caraley |first= Demetrios |title= American Hegemony: Preventive War, Iraq, and Imposing Democracy |publisher= [[Academy of Political Science]] |year= 2004 |month= April |isbn= 1-8848-5304-8}}</ref> Pro-democracy advocates in Egypt argue that this goes against the principles of [[democracy]], which include a citizen's [[right to a fair trial]] and their [[Suffrage|right to vote]] for whichever candidate or party they choose. Human rights organisations estimate that in 2010 between 5,000 and 10,000 people were in long-term detention without charge or trial,<ref>{{cite web|last=Amnesty International|title=Egypt: Keep Promise to Free Detainees by End of June|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE12/027/2010/en|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=29 June 2010}}</ref> and that in the 1990s the number of detainees was over 20,000.<ref name="eohr2008"/><ref name="Death Triggers Cairo Protests">{{cite web|author=Holder, R. Clemente|url=http://www.washington-report.org/backissues/0794/9407060.htm|title=Egyptian Lawyer's Death Triggers Cairo Protests|work=[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]|date=July/August 1994|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
The Mubarak government has used the reason of [[terrorism]] to continue extending emergency law,<ref name="eohr2008"/> and has claimed that opposition groups like the [[Muslim Brotherhood#In Egypt|Muslim Brotherhood]] could come into power in Egypt if the current government did not forgo parliamentary elections, confiscate the group's main financiers' possessions, and detain group figureheadsâactions allowed under emergency law.<ref name="autogenerated2004">{{cite book |last= Caraley |first= Demetrios |title= American Hegemony: Preventive War, Iraq, and Imposing Democracy |publisher= [[Academy of Political Science]] |year= 2004 |month= April |isbn= 1-8848-5304-8}}</ref> Pro-democracy advocates in Egypt argue that this goes against the principles of [[democracy]], which include a citizen's [[right to a fair trial]] and their [[Suffrage|right to vote]] for whichever candidate or party they choose. Human rights organisations estimate that in 2010 between 5,000 and 10,000 people were in long-term detention without charge or trial,<ref>{{cite web|last=Amnesty International|title=Egypt: Keep Promise to Free Detainees by End of June|url=http://www.amnesty.org/en/library/info/MDE12/027/2010/en|accessdate=29 January 2011|date=29 June 2010}}</ref> and that in the 1990s the number of detainees was over 20,000.<ref name="eohr2008"/><ref name="Death Triggers Cairo Protests">{{cite web|author=Holder, R. Clemente|url=http://www.washington-report.org/backissues/0794/9407060.htm|title=Egyptian Lawyer's Death Triggers Cairo Protests|work=[[Washington Report on Middle East Affairs]]|date=July/August 1994|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
===Police brutality and torture===
===Police brutality and torture===
â
[[File: Khaled Saeed by Kimo Nour.jpg|thumb|Khaled Saeed by Kimo Nour]]
 
A leaked US embassy cable from 2009 described [[police brutality]], including [[torture]], as common and pervasive, and the government's efforts to combat it as ineffective and lacking in political will.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/187359 |title=US embassy cables: Police brutality in Egypt |work=[[The Guardian]] |date 28 January 2011 |accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm |title=Egypt police sued for boy's death |work=[[BBC News]] |date=13 August 2007 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> On 6 June 2010 [[Khaled Mohamed Saeed]] died under disputed circumstances in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/anger-alexandria-we%E2%80%99re-afraid-our-own-government|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'We're afraid of our own government' |work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Two witnesses affirm Alex victim beaten by police |author= |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police |work=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=19 June 2010 |accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei leads anti-torture rally|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref>
A leaked US embassy cable from 2009 described [[police brutality]], including [[torture]], as common and pervasive, and the government's efforts to combat it as ineffective and lacking in political will.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/us-embassy-cables-documents/187359 |title=US embassy cables: Police brutality in Egypt |work=[[The Guardian]] |date 28 January 2011 |accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> The [[Egyptian Organisation for Human Rights]] has documented 567 cases of torture, including 167 deaths, by police that occurred between 1993 and 2007.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6943704.stm |title=Egypt police sued for boy's death |work=[[BBC News]] |date=13 August 2007 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> On 6 June 2010 [[Khaled Mohamed Saeed]] died under disputed circumstances in the [[Sidi Gaber]] area of [[Alexandria]]. Multiple witnesses testified that Saeed was beaten to death by the police.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/anger-alexandria-we%E2%80%99re-afraid-our-own-government|title=Anger in Alexandria: 'We're afraid of our own government' |work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Two witnesses affirm Alex victim beaten by police |author= |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/two-witnesses-affirm-alex-victim-beaten-police |work=[[Almasry Alyoum]] |date=19 June 2010 |accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> [[Mohamed ElBaradei]], former head of the [[International Atomic Energy Agency]], led a rally in Alexandria against alleged abuses by the police and visited Saeed's family to offer condolences.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201062642955204618.html|title=ElBaradei leads anti-torture rally|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=26 June 2010|accessdate=13 July 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Day of Anger riot police close.jpg|thumb|[[Paramilitary]] [[riot police]] of the [[Central Security Forces]] deployed during the 25 January protest]]
[[File:Day of Anger riot police close.jpg|thumb|[[Paramilitary]] [[riot police]] of the [[Central Security Forces]] deployed during the 25 January protest]]
